column2: The eyes of the mendicant dashed with cupidity, but he quickly suppressed his emotion.

column2: At a quarter to six o'clock, Monsieur de Gondy, having finished his business, returned to the archiepiscopal palace.
column3: At a quarter to six o'clock, Monsieur de Gondy, having finished his business, returned to the archiepiscopal palace.

column2: At six o'clock the curate of St. Merri was announced.
column3: At six o'clock the curate of st Merri was announced.

column2: Your holiness, said the curate, "here is the person of whom I had the honor to speak to you."
column3: Your holiness, said the curate, "here is the person of whom I had the honor to speak to you."

column3: Planchet saluted in the manner of one accustomed to fine houses.

column2: And you are disposed to serve the cause of the people? asked Gondy.

column2: Most undoubtedly, said Planchet.

column2: I am a Frondist from my heart.	I am a Frondist from my heart.

column2: You see in me, such as I am, a person sentenced to be hung."
column3: You see in me, such as I am, a person sentenced to be hung."

column2: And on what account?
column3: And on what account?

column2: I rescued from the hands of Mazarin's police a noble lord whom they were conducting back to the Bastile, where he had been for five years.
column3: I rescued from the hands of Mazarin's police a noble lord whom they were conducting back to the Bastile, where he had been for five years.

column2: Will you name him?
column3: Will you name him?

column2: Oh, you know him well, my lord--it is Count de Rochefort.
column3: Oh, you know him well, my lord-it is Count de Rochefort.

column2: Ah! really, yes, said the coadjutor, "I have heard this affair mentioned.
column3: Ah! really, yes, said the coadjutor, "I have heard this affair mentioned.

column2: You raised the whole district, so they told me!"
column3: You raised the whole district, so they told me!"

column2: Very nearly, replied Planchet, with a self-satisfied air.
column3: Very nearly, replied Planchet, with a self satisfied air.

column2: And your business is----
column3: And your business is----

column2: That of a confectioner, in the Rue des Lombards.
column3: That of a confectioner, in the Rue des Lombards.

column2: Explain to me how it happens that, following so peaceful a business, you had such warlike inclinations.
column3: Explain to me how it happens that, following so peaceful a business, you had such warlike inclinations.

column2: Why does my lord, belonging to the church, now receive me in the dress of an officer, with a sword at his side and spurs to his boots?
column3: Why does my lord, belonging to the church, now receive me in the dress of an officer, with a sword at his side and spurs to his boots?

column2: Not badly answered, i'faith, said Gondy, laughing; "but I have, you must know, always had, in spite of my bands, warlike inclinations."
column3: Not badly answered, i'faith, said Gondy, laughing; "but I have, you must know, always had, in spite of my bands, warlike inclinations."

column2: Well, my lord, before I became a confectioner I myself was three years sergeant in the Piedmontese regiment, and before I became sergeant I was for eighteen months the servant of Monsieur d'Artagnan.
column3: Well, my lord, before I became a confectioner I myself was three years sergeant in the Piedmontese regiment, and before I became sergeant I was for eighteen months the servant of Monsieur d'Artagnan.

column2: The lieutenant of musketeers? asked Gondy.
column3: The lieutenant of musketeers? asked Gondy.

column2: Himself, my lord.

column2: But he is said to be a furious Mazarinist.
column3: But he is said to be a furious Mazarinist.

column2: Phew! whistled Planchet.
column3: Phew! whistled Planchet.

column2: What do you mean by that?
column3: What do you mean by that?

column2: Nothing, my lord; Monsieur d'Artagnan belongs to the service; Monsieur d'Artagnan makes it his business to defend the cardinal, who pays him, as much as we make it ours, we citizens, to attack him, whom he robs.
column3: Nothing, my lord; Monsieur d'Artagnan belongs to the service; Monsieur d'Artagnan makes it his business to defend the cardinal, who pays him, as much as we make it ours, we citizens, to attack him, whom he robs.

column2: You are an intelligent fellow, my friend; can we count upon you?
column3: You are an intelligent fellow, my friend; can we count upon you?

column2: You may count upon me, my lord, provided you want to make a complete upheaval of the city.
column3: You may count upon me, my lord, provided you want to make a complete upheaval of the city.

column2: 'Tis that exactly.	'tis that exactly.

column2: How many men, think you, you could collect together to-night?"
column3: How many men, think you, you could collect together to night?"

column2: Two hundred muskets and five hundred halberds.
column3: Two hundred muskets and five hundred halberds.

column2: Let there be only one man in every district who can do as much and by to-morrow we shall have quite a powerful army.	Let there be only one man in every district who can do as much and by to morrow we shall have quite a powerful army.
column3: true

column2: Are you disposed to obey Count de Rochefort?"
column3: Are you disposed to obey Count de Rochefort?"

column2: I would follow him to hell, and that is saying not a little, as I believe him entirely capable of the descent.
column3: I would follow him to hell, and that is saying not a little, as I believe him entirely capable of the descent.

column2: Bravo!
column3: Bravo!

column2: By what sign to-morrow shall we be able to distinguish friends from foes?
column3: By what sign to morrow shall we be able to distinguish friends from foes?

column2: Every Frondist must put a knot of straw in his hat.
column3: Every Frondist must put a knot of straw in his hat.

column3: true

column2: Give the watchword."
column3: Give the watchword."

column2: Do you want money?
column3: Do you want money?

column2: Money never comes amiss at any time, my lord; if one has it not, one must do without it; with it, matters go on much better and more rapidly.
column3: Money never comes amiss at any time, my lord; if one has it not, one must do without it; with it, matters go on much better and more rapidly.

column2: Gondy went to a box and drew forth a bag.
column3: Gondy went to a box and drew forth a bag.

column2: Here are five hundred pistoles, he said; "and if the action goes off well you may reckon upon a similar sum to-morrow."
column3: Here are five hundred pistoles, he said; "and if the action goes off well you may reckon upon a similar sum to morrow."

column2: I will give a faithful account of the sum to your lordship, said Planchet, putting the bag under his arm.
column3: I will give a faithful account of the sum to your lordship, said Planchet, putting the bag under his arm.

column2: That is right; I recommend the cardinal to your attention.
column3: That is right; I recommend the cardinal to your attention.

column2: Make your mind easy, he is in good hands.
column3: Make your mind easy, he is in good hands.

column2: Planchet went out, the curate remaining for a moment.
column3: Planchet went out, the curate remaining for a moment.

column2: Are you satisfied, my lord? he asked.
column3: Are you satisfied, my lord? he asked.

column2: Yes; he appears to be a resolute fellow.
column3: Yes; he appears to be a resolute fellow.

column2: Well, he will do more than he has promised.
column3: Well, he will do more than he has promised.

column2: He will do wonders then.
column3: He will do wonders then.

column3: The curate rejoined Planchet, who was waiting for him on the stairs.

column3: As soon as the door of Gondy's study was opened a man rushed in.

column3: 'tis you, then, my dear count, cried Gondy, offering his hand.

column3: You have made up your mind at last, my lord? said Rochefort.

column3: It has been made up a long time, said Gondy.

column2: You may reckon upon me and upon fifty soldiers which the Chevalier d'Humieres has promised me whenever I need them.

column3: Upon fifty soldiers?

column3: Yes, he is making recruits and he will lend them to me; if any are missing when the fete is over, I shall replace them.

column3: What have you done with Monsieur de Beaufort?"

column2: He is in Vendome, where he will wait until I write to him to return to Paris.
column3: He is in Vendome, where he will wait until I write to him to return to Paris.

column3: Write to him; now's the time.

column2: You are sure of your enterprise?
column3: You are sure of your enterprise?

column3: Yes, but he must make haste; for hardly will the people of Paris have revolted before we shall have a score of princes begging to lead them. If he defers he will find the place of honor taken.

column3: Shall I tell him that he can count on you?

column3: And you will leave the command to him?

column3: Of the war, yes, but in politics----

column2: You care about it, then, so much?

column3: Since they force me to wear a hat of a form which does not become me, said Gondy, "I wish at least that the hat should be red."

column3: His face was pale and drawn, like that of a man who had just undergone some inward struggle.

column2: Singular man! muttered Gondy, taking his hat to go away; but on turning around he saw the beggar between him and the door.

column3: Your holiness! said Gondy; "my friend, you take me for some one else."

column3: Come, have you committed some crime, pursued by human justice, from which I can protect you?"
